phrase.item: A king had a farmer.
The farmer [named Gulabon] worked very hard planting endless watermelons and muskmelons. But when he woke up one morning, there was nothing there.
The king said, "You have been working so hard, but where does it go?
You are not checking who is taking it at night.”
He said, "Okay, king, I am going to stay up at night.
I don't know either.” [The king] said: “If you don't know,
why you have been working so hard with no result? All this hard work
Then he dug [a hole that went as far down] as his knees, to the knee.
Then he put [on top of the hole] all the dirt and the leaves from the watermelons and muskmelons. He covered it up and stayed inside [the hole].
He wanted to check from inside who was taking it,
whether it was being taken by human being or by something else.
Then he saw that fairies, about four or five hundred fairies were coming down from the mountain.
In fact they had been taking it.
They were standing 50 to 75 meters from each other and throwing [the melons].
[For example] I throw it to you, and you throw it to Jumagul and like that they were lined up.
Well, a fairy can throw very far.
And finally, [one fairy] went to the place where the covered hole was, and then she fell through it down into the hole, the fairy.
She fell inside and he held her by the hem of her dress,
the farmer.
He caught her and said: “Now…” She said, "Let me go, you human being made of dirt.” He said, "Don't say human being made of dirt. I have a soul from God and you also have it.
God created both of us, you are mistaken.”
Then
he said, "I will marry you.” And then he married her and they had two chidren,
a daughter and a son.

Well, then in the end she stayed there [with him], and he beat? her, and she turned into something long and thin and went off into the sky, got out of there. Then out of anger he took his children and put one on his right side and the other on his left side.
Their heads stayed there, becoming like one body with three heads, a three-headed [person].
Then himself, he... Then he went to [the farmer] Gulabon—
oh, first the writer came [to the farmer Gulabon], asking questions and went to Gulabon.
Then [the writer] asked [the farmer], "Why did you put this [bird] in the cage? What it has done wrong?"
He said, "If you really want to know, I will tell you.”
He said, "She was my old woman, my wife.
Whenever she used to sleep with me, whenever I fell asleep... So, one day I slept and noticed that slowly-slowly, she was moving away from me.
Other times I was sleeping, but that day I kept eye on her. just pretending.
Then
she set out on a foal, all the foals were fat, only one was skinny. She rode that [foal] for about 11 kilometers.
She went far, from here to Imtshun.
There was a demon and she knew him,[the man's] wife, that lady.
Gulabon's wife [I mean]. Then [Gulabon] also rode a horse and followed her, he saw that the demon threw her, saying, "You came late.”
She told him, "Well, my husband fell asleep late.
[He wouldn’t let me go].”
Then there the demon started fighting [with her] and [Gulabon] went back,
went back and went to bed before she could come back. After, his wife also came back and went to bed. Usually the wife woke up early in the morning, but that day the husband woke up early.
When the wife got up, the husband was puffing [air] with a "puurrrff" sound and she turned into a bird.
She turned into a bird, he caught her and put her in a cage.

She was in the cage, he threw bread to the dog, and he himself also had breakfast [dinner] in the morning. And he threw the dog's leftover crumbs [from his mouth] to the bird into [the cage] saying, "So that was my wife,
since you wanted to know.” The [writer] was taking notes.
So that was the story.
